are switch controllers and other bluetooth controllers allowed and if they are how would I use them? thanks!

As far as I know, wired controllers are required. They can have Bluetooth capability, but they must be wired so an Xbox controller must be plugged in, but it’s still legal.

No. R905 clearly prohibits them.

I don’t know with certainty, but I imagine they’re worried about possible interference in the RF spectrum and about being able to take input from an unbounded variety of sources. (If wireless is allowed, whose to say what the source of the wireless instruction/input to the operator console is. Could scouts or coaches in the stands be processing information and relaying inputs to the robot? Probably a lot harder if you bar wireless comms [and a lot easier to drop a ban hammer if they get caught].)

i see your point it’s like giving a controller to someone with no batteris and saying they are conrolling it but someone else is

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-01-21T00:59:54.250Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":159,"readers_count":158,"score":31.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":482822,"topic_slug":"switch-controller","display_username":"hank","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":71594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2024"},"post_url":"/t/switch-controller/482822/7","custom_user_title":"2024","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3488776,"name":"Nathan Shepherd","username":"NShep98","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nshep98/{size}/224800_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-21T05:42:18.459Z","cooked":"

If wireless controllers are allowed, that gives you a lot less certainty that your drivers are the ones driving the robot. I could sneakily be giving controller inputs during auto. My Technician could be driving. The person on the side of the field with a media badge could be driving. It’s way easier to just have a blanket restriction on wireless control.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-01-21T05:42:18.459Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":121,"readers_count":120,"score":54.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":482822,"topic_slug":"switch-controller","display_username":"Nathan Shepherd","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":25762,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2079 A -> 246 M -> 1153/1119 M"},"post_url":"/t/switch-controller/482822/8","custom_user_title":"2079 A -> 246 M -> 1153/1119 M","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3488785,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-21T06:15:15.051Z","cooked":"

One other possibility with wireless controllers:

It’s possible–at least in theory–that if your controllers are wireless, they’re communicating directly to the robot.

This raises all kinds of safety and fairness issues, from “how do we know that robot won’t move while humans are on the field?” to “how do we guarantee that nobody either jumps the gun or drags their figurative feet for more time in the match?” Not to mention the aforementioned wireless interference issues.

I mean, direct non-VH-109 wireless is banned by R702 and R706 and R707–but I can think of a couple of possible “workarounds” particularly if I’m not particularly concerned about following rules. (Whether those workarounds are actually possible? Not my field of expertise.)

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-01-21T06:15:15.051Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":105,"readers_count":104,"score":56.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":482822,"topic_slug":"switch-controller","display_username":"EricH","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://frctools.com/2025/rule/R707","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Rule R707 | FRCTools","clicks":2},{"url":"https://frctools.com/2025/rule/R702","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Rule R702 | FRCTools","clicks":1},{"url":"https://frctools.com/2025/rule/R706","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Rule R706 | FRCTools","clicks":1}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":4212,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"#westandwithUkraine"},"post_url":"/t/switch-controller/482822/9","custom_user_title":"#westandwithUkraine","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3488828,"name":"Trevor Dayal (he/him)","username":"TrevDay","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/trevday/{size}/268067_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-21T12:38:22.320Z","cooked":"

I’m curious as to why you’d want to run a switch controller. There are a few reasons I wouldn’t, regardless of the legality:

  1. Having your drivers account for controller drift while driving could reduce your performance.
  2. Potential lag from using a wireless controller may prevent your drivers from quick reactions against defense.
  3. Nintendo switch controllers are not as versatile as other options (no buttons on back of controller, non-variable triggers, less community support)

If you are looking for a controller, I recommend one that AM sells.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-01-21T12:38:41.084Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":68,"readers_count":67,"score":13.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":482822,"topic_slug":"switch-controller","display_username":"Trevor Dayal (he/him)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.andymark.com/products/gamesir-g7-se-xbox-style-wired-controller","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"GameSir-G7 SE Xbox Style Wired Controller - AndyMark, Inc","clicks":11}],"read":true,"user_title":"Regular","title_is_group":false,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":59182,"hidden":false,"trust_level":3,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"happy day!"},"post_url":"/t/switch-controller/482822/10","custom_user_title":"happy day!","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3488844,"name":"Steven Carmain","username":"Steven_Carmain","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/f07891/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-21T13:16:27.687Z","cooked":"

The other problem is say all teams have 2 wireless controllers. That means you have 12 Bluetooth devices on the field, plus everyone also running wireless headphones/Airpods, and hotspots (either banned WiFi points or technically legal Bluetooth points), and the 2.4GHz traffic/noise from the buildings, and there is no way to reliably have wireless signals for the controllers.

That is part of the reason the new radios went to the mostly unused 6GHz band, much less congestion, less devices use it, and higher bandwidths.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-01-21T13:16:27.687Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":49,"readers_count":48,"score":9.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":482822,"topic_slug":"switch-controller","display_username":"Steven Carmain","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":1737,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programmer/Drive Coach"},"post_url":"/t/switch-controller/482822/11","custom_user_title":"Programmer/Drive Coach","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3488846,"name":"Mr. Siefen | 453","username":"kingc95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kingc95/{size}/226662_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-21T13:23:32.699Z","cooked":"

Switch controllers can be legal, they must be wired ones that don’t operate in wireless mode (permanently wired is best for reliability and to ensure there is 0 wireless capability). There are plenty out there that are often cheaper than the official wireless pro controllers. In some cases the Smash Bros edition controllers come with extra long cables, which can be a bonus, or a tripping hazard…

Additionally there are USB variants of most popular ‘retro’ controllers that you can find and legally use. I have N64, Sega Genesis, NES, SNES and Gamecube controllers all USB version for emulation at home. I have brought these in for robotics on occasion, but usually a wired Xbox one/360 controller is the driver preference for a gamepad.
